description: Designed in the early 1970s by the USSR, the APS underwater assault rifle is weapon designed to fulfill a very particular niche: combat against enemy combat divers attacking Soviet harbors and naval assets. Unlike its more conventional assualt rifle brethren, the APS fires a flechette-like spear out of a smoothbore barrel and relies on hydronamic effects in order to maintain accuracy. It is nearly useless on land.
A large slab-like magazine designed for use with the APS underwater rifle. Contains 26 rounds of the elongated 5.66x120mm steel spear ammunition.

A large slab-like magazine designed for use with the APS underwater rifle. Contains 20 roundsof the elongated 5.66x120mm steel spear ammunition. This variant is makeshift and thus of a generally lower quality.

First developed by the italian inventor Bartolomeo Girardoni in the 1770s, the Girardoni air rifle was among the few long arms before the 19th century that was capable of firing multiple times without a lengthy reloading process. This was achieved by the rifle's use of compressed air rather than combustible powder as its main source of energy. Such a peculiar energy source for the time came at a price, though: the weapon was fairly unreliable despite the advantages it brought to the table that made it in many ways a peerless weapon. Has a VERY long reload time to account for charging the weapon's compressed air bottle.

A reproduction of the famed West German Heckler and Koch G11 of famed technological complexity and 'German Space Magic'. Although fairly unremarkable in actual performance for its day, the G11 gained something of a cult following after German reunification dashed hopes of the weapon's broad adoptment. In some way's the rifle's technological advancement was its own undoing: the gun's peculiar caseless round proving to be less capable of dissipating heat then conventional brass ammunition, in addition to being harder to care for in the field. Rivtech eventually realized that there was the potential for a small but dedicated consumer market around the G11, and elected to make faithful reproductions with the notable exception of using proprietaty 8mm casless ammunition as opposed to the G11's 4.7mm caseless ammunition.
A 45 round box magazine for use with Rivtech 8x40mm variant of the G11.

The TRW Low Maintenance Rifle was a prototype automatic rifle chambered for 5.56 developed for use by poorly-equipped troops in cold war hotspots across the globe (especially vietnam). Considered to be the American response to the AK-47, the TRW Low Mainteance rifle prioritized ease of use, cost effectivness and ruggedness above all else, sporting only automatic fire and semi-permanent lubricrants in the place of the more complex mechanical innards of the early M16 rifles. Accepts standard STANAG magazines.

A Pietta reproduction of the civil war era LeMat carbine, a rare and unusual cap & ball .44-caliber rifle.  While its original non-standard .42 or .35 caliber curbed its usefulness for the CSA army, this reproduction is offered in more prevalent .44 caliber.  Despite modern quality materials, the design is still rather delicate. This variant of the lemat is the far more rare carbine type that was made in small numbers for the confederate military during the civil war. Due to the lengthened barrel, the lemat carbine derives slightly more power from it's .44 ammo.

A small, lightweight carbine designed for use with rear echelon support troops in the second world war after a lengthy and competitive design process. Lightweight, fairly accurate and with a passable (although somewhat anemic by later standards) cartridge, the m1 carbine was loved by troops and saw wide use in both the civilian market and post war militaries for decades.

A small, lightweight carbine designed for use with rear echelon support troops in the second world war after a lengthy and competitive design process. Lightweight, fairly accurate and with a passable (although somewhat anemic by later standards) cartridge, this is the m2 variant: featuring a select fire option allowing semi-automatic or fully-automatic fire. Whether or not it constitutes an assault rifle is up for debate.

A small, .30 caliber carbine develped by an obscure inventor from Pennsylvania and submitted as part of the competition to make the famed M1 carbine. Unlike every other rifle, this carbine is made entirely of metal and did not perform well in testing on account of its poor durability. Remodelled to accept m1 carbine magazines.
A compact 15-round box magazine used with the m1 or m2 carbines.
A makeshift compact 15-round box magazine used with the m1 or m2 carbines.
A compact 30-round box magazine used with the m1 or m2 carbines.

A derivative of the Type 30 rifle made in 1897, the Type 38 rifle, commonly known as the 'Arisaka' in the west, was the premier rifle of the Japanese Empire during its attempted conquest of East Asia. The rifle's cartridge is fairly anemic compared to other bolt action rifles of its day, with the advantage of reduced recoil and noise. Features a dust cover that was often removed due to the rattling noise it made in daily use.

A derivative of the Type 30 rifle made in 1897, the Type 38 rifle, commonly known as the 'Arisaka' in the west, was the premier rifle of the Japanese Empire during its attempted conquest of East Asia. The rifle's cartridge is fairly anemic compared to other bolt action rifles of its day, with the advantage of reduced recoil and noise. Features a dust cover that was often removed due to the rattling noise it made in daily use. This is the carbine variant of the Arisaka, intended for use with support troops.
A tiny piece of grooved metal designed to allow a shooter to quickly load a bolt-action rifle.

A derivative of the Type 30 rifle made in 1897, the Type 38 rifle, commonly known as the 'Arisaka' in the west, was the premier rifle of the Japanese Empire during its attempted conquest of East Asia. This variant of Arisaka post-dates the Type 38 Arisaka, and features the more powerful 7.7mm Arisaka. Features a dust cover that was often removed due to the rattling noise it made in daily use.
A tiny piece of grooved metal designed to allow a shooter to quickly load a bolt-action rifle.

Derived from the need for a small arm capable of providing wide fields of covering fire during the Russo Japanese War and WW1, the Type 11 is an air-cooled light machine gun chambered for the 6.5mm Arisaka cartridge. Unique to the type 11 is its rather quixotic method of ammo storage, featuring a hopper storing six stripper clips worth of 6.5mm ammunition, with each clip being deposited as it was stripped of its cartridges. The Type 11 poorly utilizeed standard 6.5mm rounds, and as such the anemic 6.5mm 'genso' cartridge was designed for use with the machine gun. Unfortunately CDDA can't accomdate multiple clips in one weapon so this firearm can't really use multiple clips at once, or any at all really.

An export version of the Japanese Howa Type 64 battle rifle developed for use with the Japanese Ground Self Defense Force. In most ways it is entirely unremarkable as a battle rifle and doesn't really stand out among its contemporaries. As this variant was made for the export market its internal mechanisms were reinforced to accomodate full-strength 7.62 ammunition instead of the slightly weaker 7.62 round designed for Japanese use.
A lightweight box magazine for the Howa Type 64 battle rifle.
A lightweight box magazine for the Howa Type 64 battle rifle.

An assault rifle designed to replace the 7.62mm Howa Type 64 battle rifle for use with the Japanese Ground Self Defense Forces. It is essentially a derivative of the Armalite AR-18 and is cheaper to produce than the Howa Type 64.

Arguably considered (with much debate) to be the first assault rifle ever made, and definitely the first fielded in any appreciable number, the Sturmgewehr 44 was fielded by Nazi Germany during the later days of the Second World War. Designed to be controllable under fully automatic fire and hit targets several hundred meters away with the pared-down 7.92mm kurz round, the STG 44 codified the basic design structure of the assault rifle we all know and love today.

A prototype assault rifle produced at the very end of ww2, intended to be an easier to produce replacement for the famed STG-45 assault rifle. Unlike its more famous predecssor, the STG-45 uses a recoil operated roller-delayed blowback system. To a slight degree, the STG-45 influenced post-war assault rifle design.

Designed during the desperate last days of ww2 when volkssturm were considered for use as front line infantry, the VG 1-5, or Volkssturmgewehr, was intended for use as an easy to manufacture semi-automatic rifle for use with untrained infantry. Made almost entirely of stamped metal parts for ease of manufacture in the vain hope that these crude weapons would be able to resist the allied onslaught.
A standard 30-round magazine for 7.92x33mm kurz Sturmgewehr rifles, made of stamped sheet metal.
A standard 10-round magazine for 7.92x33mm kurz Sturmgewehr rifles, made of stamped sheet metal.
A makeshift 15-round magazine for 7.92x33mm kurz Sturmgewehr rifles, made of scrap metal.

The Remington Model 8 is a semi-automatic rifle designed by John Browning and produced by Remington Arms. It is long recoil-operated and uses a rotating bolt head. After firing, the barrel and bolt, still locked together, move rearward inside the receiver and compress two recoil springs. Then the bolt is held back while the barrel is returned forward by one of the springs permitting extraction and ejection .
A light-weight stripper clip for use with the Remington Model 8.

The EM-2, or Janson Rifle, was a groundbreaking bullpup rifle designed by the British Army at the height of the cold war. Revolutionary for its time, it features an integrated optic above a carrying rail affixed to the receiver. Due to the rarity of the .280 British cartridge, this rifle has been modified to fire the far more numerous .223 caliber cartridges of the United States.
A standard capacity 20-round box magazine for use with EM-2 rifle.
A makeshift standard capacity 30-round box magazine for use with EM-2 rifle.

An iconic prototype firearm produced in very small numbers during the 1960s. Unlike the vast majority of firearms, the gyrojet family of weapons uses a small rocket propelled-projectile, with the lethality of its projectile being at maximum some distance after the muzzle. Due to the rocket-propelled projectile at the heart of the gyrojet system, gyrojet weapons could be made to be very lightweight on account of having little recoil, and very quiet as well. Despite their advanced features, the gyrojets were marred by development problems, anemic damage output at close range and general inaccuracy. This is a rifle variant of the gyrojet system, essentially a longer barrel and stock attached to the gyrojet pistol.

An iconic prototype firearm produced in very small numbers during the 1960s. Unlike the vast majority of firearms, the gyrojet family of weapons uses a small rocket propelled-projectile, with the lethality of its projectile being at maximum some distance after the muzzle. Due to the rocket-propelled projectile at the heart of the gyrojet system, gyrojet weapons could be made to be very lightweight on account of having little recoil, and very quiet as well. Despite their advanced features, the gyrojets were marred by development problems, anemic damage output at close range and general inaccuracy. This is a rifle variant of the gyrojet system, essentially a longer barrel and stock attached to the gyrojet pistol. This is a custom gyrojet variant, being slightly accurized and with a magazine well, in addition to accomodations for various mods.

The Kammerlader, or 'chamber loader' was among the first breech-loading rifles employed by any army in the developed world. Developed by Denmark in the mid 1800s, the Kamerlader featured an then innovating swivelling breech bore, enabling it to become a rapidly firing and accurate rifle compared to its muzzle-loading contemporaries.

An English-made muzzle-loading rifle with world-reknowned accuracy, famously used during the American Civil War during the Confederate Sharpshooters. The accuracy comes at a price though, the rifle's unique hexagonal rifling necessitates the usage of a unique hexagonal bullet and the rifle has a large reload time.

A .22lr surival rifle originally made for use by downed pilots for the U.S. Air Force. Designed by the famed firearms engineer Eugene Stoner, the AR-7 uses a conventional blowback action and is a takedown firearm, with its components capable of being stored in its stock.
Removable 8-round box magazine for the rsw_ar7mag15 AR-7.
Removable 10-round box magazine for the Armalite AR-7.
Removable 15-round box magazine for the Armalite AR-7.
Removable 8-round makeshift box magazine for the Armalite AR-7.

name.str_sp: Colt First Model Ring Lever Rifle

description: An early caplock rifle produced by the famed engineer Samuel Colt, the Colt Ring Lever rifle is an early multi-shot rifle developed slightly before the arrival of its far more famous sister, the Colt Paterson. The design and action was fairly complex for its day, featuring an 8 or 10 round cylinder that was actuated by pulling on a small ring in front of the trigger guard. Despite their complexity they saw combat with the U.S. Army during the Seminole war. As this is a modern reproduction, it avoids some of the problems with the chain-firing seen on initial production runs of cap and ball revolving rifles.
This cylinder can hold 8 rounds of .36 caliber cap and ball to use with the Colt Ring Lever Rifle.
This cylinder can hold 8 rounds of .36 caliber cap and ball to use with the Colt Ring Lever Rifle.

An iconic prototype firearm produced in very small numbers during the 1960s. Unlike the vast majority of firearms, the gyrojet family of weapons uses a small rocket propelled-projectile, with the lethality of its projectile being at maximum some distance after the muzzle. Due to the rocket-propelled projectile at the heart of the gyrojet system, gyrojet weapons could be made to be very lightweight on account of having little recoil, and very quiet as well. Despite their advanced features, the gyrojets were marred by development problems, anemic damage output at close range and general inaccuracy. This is a very rare variant of gyrojet rifle, equipped with a ballistic computer, scope and wire-guided guidance system for gyrojet smart rounds.

Intended as a weapon for use by the desperate volkssturm national defense militias in the last days of the Third Reich, the HIW VSK, or HIW Volkssturmkarabiner is a semi-automatic blow-forward firearm. It is chambered for the 7.92x33mm Kurz round and has a peculiar action that is a mixture of a double-action revolver and forward moving barrel. It's only real positive trait is that it's fairly easy to make.

A full-length rifle chambered for the 7.7mm Arisaka cartridge, if it can even be called a rifle. This is little more than a barrel on a crude wooden plank that can only fire a single shot at a time, as crude as it gets. Intended for use by Japanese soldiers (and civilians) for the invasion of Japan that never came.

A 15 round pistol that is essentially a hybrid between a magazine-fed pistol and a revolver. The gun uses cartridges known as 'trounds', essentially .38 or .22 caliber pistol cartridges wrapped by a triangular plastic casing that extends to the tip of the bullet. These pistols were developed by the engineer Richard Dardick and saw little popularity on account of their expensive price, odd ammo and generally ungainly dimensions. This variant has been outfitted with a carbine module, allowing for a much longer barrel and butt stock.
